addPasswordHint: Al crear una contraseña a continuación, podrá iniciar sesión con su nombre de usuario o dirección de correo electrónico y contraseña. También ayudará a mantener su cuenta más segura porque le solicitaremos la contraseña antes de realizar cualquier cambio.

addStudentsSyncThirdParty: Sincronizar mi lista de estudiantes desde una sección de aula existente en una herramienta de terceros

addStudentsToSectionInstructions: Elige cómo quieres agregar a tus estudiantes:
addStudentsToSectionInstructionsUpdated: ¿Cómo quieres que tus alumnos inicien sesión?
addStudentsToSectionPermissionExplanatio: Para las clases que tengan niños menores de 13 años, recomendamos encarecidamente que cree cuentas para los estudiantes utilizando contraseñas con imágenes o palabras secretas para toda la clase. Este enfoque no requiere que Code.org recopile información personal de los estudiantes o sobre ellos. La creación de inicios de sesión personales por parte de estudiantes menores de 13 años puede requerir un paso de consentimiento parental independiente (es decir, un correo electrónico al padre/tutor y una respuesta afirmativa) que podría retrasar o impedir la creación de la cuenta e interferir con la participación en el aula.
addStudentsToSectionPermissionHeader: Si los estudiantes de tu clase tienen menos de 13 años:
addStudentsToSectionPermissionWarning: Le recomendamos encarecidamente que no utilice inicios de sesión personales. El uso de inicios de sesión personales puede requerir el consentimiento de los padres por razones de seguridad y privacidad.
adminAccountDeletionDialog_body: Estás a punto de eliminar una cuenta de administrador. ¿Estás seguro de que deseas continuar?

administratorResourcesHeading: Amplíe la informática en su escuela o distrito
afeBannerCongrats: ¡Felicitaciones! Puedes acceder a los recursos de Amazon Future Engineer sin costo alguno.
afeBannerParagraph: Amazon Future Engineer ofrece soporte para las aulas de Code.org, incluidos carteles, membresía CSTA+, oportunidades de pasantías y becas, y acceso a recursos de computación en la nube sin costo.
afeCompleteTheFormBelow: Complete el formulario a continuación para acceder a recursos gratuitos y relevantes para usted y sus estudiantes.
afeContinueMessage: Si continúas, recibirás correos electrónicos de Amazon Future Engineer para solicitar beneficios y actualizaciones sobre becas, subvenciones y más. Puedes cambiar tus preferencias o cancelar la suscripción en cualquier momento.
afeInspirationKit: Envíame un kit de agradecimiento con artículos de la marca Amazon Future Engineer (camisetas, vasos, pegatinas y mucho más).
afeSupport: ¿Cómo puede Amazon Future Engineer ayudarle a usted y a sus estudiantes?
aiAssessmentAll: Evaluación de IA para todos los proyectos no presentados
aiAssessmentsAnnouncementBody: El asistente de enseñanza de IA evaluará los proyectos de los estudiantes, sugerirá puntajes de rúbrica y resaltará el código donde se cumple cada requisito, lo que lo ayudará a ahorrar tiempo al evaluar el trabajo de los estudiantes. Estas funciones están disponibles para los proyectos y miniproyectos de esta unidad.
aiAssessmentsAnnouncementHeading: ¡Ya están disponibles evaluaciones respaldadas por IA!
aiCannotAssess: Este objetivo de aprendizaje es demasiado subjetivo para que la IA lo evalúe.
aiChatBotIconAlt: Un icono que representa un robot.
aiChatInappropriateModelMessage: La respuesta del chatbot ha sido marcada por nuestra política de moderación de contenido. Intente con otro mensaje
aiChatInappropriateUserMessage: Este mensaje ha sido marcado por nuestra política de moderación de contenido. Intente con otro mensaje.
aiChatMessageBot: Mensaje de chat del robot de IA
aiChatNotAuthorizedSignedOut: Para poder utilizar esta herramienta, debes ser un docente registrado o un estudiante registrado en una sección del aula.
aiChatNotAuthorizedStudent: Para poder utilizar esta herramienta, debes estar en una sección del aula. Consulta con tu profesor si crees que esto es un error.
aiChatNotAuthorizedTeacher: Para utilizar esta herramienta, debes ser un profesor verificado o tener una cuenta con inicio de sesión único habilitado.
aiChatRateLimitError: Has enviado demasiados mensajes en el último minuto. Espera un momento antes de enviar otro mensaje.
aiChatResponseError: Se produjo un error al obtener una respuesta. Inténtalo nuevamente.
aiChatTooPersonalUserMessage: Este mensaje ha sido marcado como demasiado personal.
aiChatUserInputTooLargeMessage: AI Chat solo puede procesar cierta cantidad de información y tu último mensaje utilizó demasiadas palabras. Borra el chat o acorta tu último mensaje, mensaje del sistema o recuperación para continuar chateando.
aiConfidenceTooltip: El puntaje de confianza se calcula a partir de qué tan bien funcionó la evaluación de IA para este objetivo de aprendizaje en nuestro conjunto de capacitación de proyectos de estudiantes. Preste especial atención a los proyectos con confianza media o baja.
aiEvaluationDetails: La evaluación de IA se ejecuta automáticamente cuando un estudiante presiona "Enviar" para su proyecto. Si los estudiantes olvidan enviarlo, puede ejecutar la evaluación de IA para toda la clase usando el botón de arriba o ejecutarla para un estudiante individual mientras ve su rúbrica.
aiEvaluationStatusAll_already_evaluated: Análisis de IA ya completado para todos los proyectos estudiantiles disponibles.
aiEvaluationStatusAll_not_attempted: Ningún estudiante ha intentado este nivel. No hay análisis de IA disponible.
aiEvaluationStatusAll_ready: Se puede generar análisis de IA para {unevaluatedCount} proyectos de estudiantes.
aiEvaluationStatusAll_summary: La evaluación de IA se ha ejecutado con éxito para {evaluatedCount} / {totalCount} proyectos de estudiantes.
aiEvaluationStatus_already_evaluated: Análisis de IA ya completado para este proyecto.
aiEvaluationStatus_error: No se puede completar el análisis de IA debido a un error. Inténtalo de nuevo más tarde o ponte en contacto con el servicio de asistencia.

aiEvaluationStatus_pending: El análisis de IA está en la cola

aiEvaluationStatus_profanity_error: El análisis de IA no se puede completar debido a una blasfemia en el código del estudiante.
aiEvaluationStatus_request_too_large: El análisis de IA falló debido a la extensión del código del estudiante. Nuestro equipo está solucionando el problema. Califique manualmente el proyecto de este estudiante mientras tanto.
aiEvaluationStatus_teacher_limit_exceede: Este trabajo no fue evaluado porque ya alcanzó el límite de {limit} evaluaciones de IA para este estudiante en este nivel.
aiFeedbackNegativeWhy: ¿Por qué la evaluación de IA es inexacta? (Marque todas las opciones que correspondan).

announcementDescriptionYouTubeNoCookie: Estamos actualizando nuestros requisitos de TI para el próximo año escolar, lo que puede afectar la capacidad de algunas escuelas para acceder a subtítulos y traducciones en videos. Este cambio entrará en vigencia a fines de julio.

announcementHoc2023DanceAIBody: Learn about artificial intelligence (AI) concepts to create your own virtual dance party showcasing today's top artists. With dozens of songs to choose from, reach every student no matter their music taste. It's time to strut your stuff!

censusHowManyTwentyHours: ¿Cuántos estudiantes toman un curso de informática de un semestre o de un año de duración que incluye al menos 20 horas de codificación/programación de computadoras?

censusPledge: Me comprometo a ampliar la oferta de ciencias de la computación en mi escuela y a involucrar a un grupo diverso de estudiantes, para brindar oportunidades a todos.

childAccountConsentEmailUnknown: No almacenamos las direcciones de correo electrónico de los estudiantes en un formato recuperable, por lo que no podemos comunicarnos con ellos directamente.
childAccountConsentExpiredHeader: Lo sentimos, el enlace ha expirado.
childAccountConsentExpiredMessage: Parece que has hecho clic en un enlace de aprobación antiguo. Pídele a tu hijo que vuelva a ingresar o vuelve a enviar el correo electrónico de aprobación de los padres. Deberías recibir un correo electrónico de aprobación dentro de las 24 horas posteriores al nuevo intento.
childAccountConsentValidMessage: ¡Gracias por aprobar la cuenta de Code.org de su hijo! Recibirá un correo electrónico de confirmación en un plazo de 24 a 48 horas. ¡Infórmele a su hijo que ha aprobado su cuenta para que pueda comenzar a aprender y codificar hoy mismo!
childAccountPolicy_CreateSectionsWarning: Si tiene estudiantes menores de 13 años, es posible que necesiten el consentimiento de los padres para usar un inicio de sesión personal. Vuelva atrás y use una contraseña con imagen, una palabra secreta o secciones administradas por la escuela para evitar interrupciones a los estudiantes menores de 13 años.
childAccountPolicy_ageGatedSectionsModal: Visite las secciones vinculadas a continuación para ver qué estudiantes requerirán el consentimiento de los padres.
Secciones que requieren el consentimiento de los padres

Las siguientes secciones tienen estudiantes menores de 13 años que usan cuentas personales. Necesitarán el consentimiento de los padres después del {startDate} para continuar usando Code.org con sus cuentas personales.
Lea más sobre este proceso de consentimiento y estos cambios aquí.
childAccountPolicy_ageGatedSectionsWarni: Algunas de sus secciones tienen estudiantes menores de 13 años que usan cuentas personales para iniciar sesión. Estos estudiantes necesitarán el consentimiento de los padres para continuar usando sus cuentas personales después del {startDate}.

childAccountPolicy_studentParentalConsen: Los siguientes estudiantes necesitarán el consentimiento de sus padres después del {startDate} para continuar usando Code.org con su cuenta personal. Asegúrese de que estos estudiantes proporcionen una dirección de correo electrónico de sus padres o tutores para completar el proceso de consentimiento de sus padres.

courseBlocksCsfExpressDescription: A great option for students getting started on their own.  You'll learn the fundamentals of computer science with drag & drop blocks.  Create your own drawings and games.
courseBlocksCsfOlderDescription: For older students in elementary school classrooms
courseBlocksCsfYoungDescription: For pre-readers in elementary school classrooms
courseBlocksCsfYoungHeading: Computer Science Fundamentals for Elementary Schools
courseBlocksGradeBands612Description: Build real working apps, games and websites using blocks, JavaScript, CSS, HTML and more.
courseBlocksGradeBandsContainerDescripti: Browse our catalog of courses from Code Studio and 3rd party partners.
courseBlocksGradeBandsElementaryDescript: Teachers say our elementary courses are "totally awesome sauce" and fun for all students, even pre-readers.
courseBlocksGradeBandsHighDescription: We offer two year-long courses for high school: an intro course and an AP course. Both are designed to broaden participation in computer science.
courseBlocksGradeBandsK5Description: Learn to make your own game, app, or computer drawing.
courseBlocksGradeBandsMiddleDescription: Our new middle school course can be offered as a semester or year-long introduction to computer science for all students.
courseBlocksGradeBandsUniversityDescript: Take the next step on your CS Journey. Explore career paths, extended learning, scholarships, internships, and more.
courseBlocksInternationalGradeBandsConta: Below is the catalog of all of our courses and great options from third parties. Please note that some of these are only in English. Don't worry -- we're working on getting these courses translated into your language. Thanks for your patience!
courseBlocksInternationalGradeBandsEleme: CS Fundamentals offers a variety of courses for students to explore programming concepts, computational thinking, digital citizenship, and to develop interactive games and stories.
courseBlocksInternationalGradeBandsHighD: We offer two courses for secondary school: CS Discoveries and CS Principles. Both are designed to broaden participation in computer science.
courseBlocksInternationalGradeBandsMiddl: As flexible courses that can be taught in a unit, semester, or full year, CS Discoveries and CS Fundamentals Express introduce students to app design, JavaScript programming, physical computing, and more.
courseBlocksLegacyNotificationBody: Were you using Courses 1-4 or the Accelerated Course? They’re still available! Our transition guide will help you find the right course for your classroom.
courseBlocksLegacyNotificationHeading: CS Fundamentals Courses 1-4 & the Accelerated Course
courseBlocksLegacyNotificationSupportEnd: Courses 1-4 and the Accelerated Course are still available, but we have better options now. Our transition guide will help you get started with Courses A-F, which teach the same concepts more effectively, are actively supported, and have full translation into over 30 languages.
Courses 1-4 & the Accelerated Course are outdated!
courseBlocksToolsAiDescription: Students will learn the fundamentals of artificial intelligence and machine learning and discuss their implications. Suitable for grades 6-12.
courseBlocksToolsAppLabDescription: App Lab is a programming environment where you can make simple apps. Design an app, code with blocks or JavaScript to make it work, then share your app in seconds.
courseBlocksToolsDescription: In addition to our courses, teachers can use tools to teach students how to create apps, animations, games, or websites. We also have lessons and widgets to teach encryption, text compression, and other computer science concepts. Browse our other resources to inspire students with posters, videos, or by inviting guest speakers.
courseBlocksToolsGameLabDescription: Game Lab is a programming environment where you can make simple animations and games with objects and characters that interact with each other.
courseBlocksToolsInspireDescription: Find a volunteer guest speaker or use these videos, posters, and how-to resources to inspire students to try computer science.
courseBlocksToolsTitleNonEn: Tools for middle and high school (English only)
courseBlocksToolsTitleTeacher: Tools and resources for your classroom
courseBlocksToolsVideoDescription: These videos can be used in any computer science course to support learning.
courseBlocksToolsWebLabDescription: Web Lab is a programming environment where you can make simple web pages using HTML and CSS. Design your web pages and share your site in seconds.
courseBlocksToolsWidgetsDescription: Students can explore concepts from our CS Principles course hands-on using these digital tools. Use the widgets on their own, or create a single-concept lesson for your class.
courseCatalogDescription: Code.org offers courses across K-12 at no cost to schools. And, if you’d like help getting started, we also offer online professional learning at no cost.
courseExplorerDescription: Courses from Code.org for students in grades K-12 and professional learning for teachers.
courseInYourLanguage: Curriculum is available in your language
courseInfoCscDescription: This curriculum makes the connections between learning computer science and traditional subjects like math, language arts, science, and social studies. Through CS Connections, any classroom can explore its usual subjects in exciting new ways!
courseOfferingCSC: Conexiones a las Ciencias de la Computación
courseOfferingCSF: Fundamentos de Ciencias de la Computación
coursesCardDescription: Find a new course to keep challenging yourself.
coursesLearnHeroDescription: Get started coding today. Our courses and activities are free! It’s easier - and way more fun - than you ever thought. Create an account to save your projects.

coursesTeachHeroDescription: More than one million teachers have brought CS to their students using Code.org. We make it easy, no matter your background.
coursesTeachHeroSubHeading: You don't have to be a software developer to teach computer science.

csfDescription: Start learning an introduction to computer science on Code Studio with these 20 hour courses for all ages.
csfDescriptionTeacher: Free set of elementary curricula that introduces students to the foundational concepts of computer science and challenges them to explore how computing and technology can impact the world.

dropletBlock_andOperator_description: Returns true only when both expressions are true and false otherwise
dropletBlock_assign_x_description: Assigns a value to a previously declared variable.
dropletBlock_callMyFunction_description: Calls a named function that takes no parameters.
dropletBlock_callMyFunction_n_descriptio: Calls a user defined function that takes one or more parameters.
dropletBlock_comment_description: Write a description of some code
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_array_1_4_d: Declares a variable and assigns it to an array with the given initial values
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_array_1_4_s: Declare a variable assigned to an array
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_description: Declares and assigns an initial value to a variable.
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_promptNum_d: Declares that the code will now use a variable and assign it an initial numerical value provided by the user
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_promptNum_s: Prompt the user for a numerical value and store it
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_prompt_desc: Declares that the code will now use a variable and assign it an initial value provided by the user
dropletBlock_declareAssign_x_prompt_sign: Prompt the user for a value and store it
dropletBlock_declareNoAssign_x_descripti: Declares a variable with the given name.
dropletBlock_equalityOperator_descriptio: Test whether two values are equal. Returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the expression equals the value on the right-hand side of the expression, and false otherwise.
dropletBlock_forLoop_i_0_4_description: Creates a loop consisting of an initialization expression, a conditional expression, an incrementing expression, and a block of statements executed for each iteration of the loop.
dropletBlock_functionParams_n_descriptio: Gives a name to a set of parameter driven actions for the computer to perform.
dropletBlock_functionParams_none_descrip: Gives a name to a set of actions you want the computer to perform.
dropletBlock_getTime_description: Get the current time in milliseconds.
dropletBlock_greaterThanOperator_descrip: Tests whether a number is greater than another number. Returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the expression is strictly greater than the value on the right-hand side of the expression.
dropletBlock_greaterThanOrEqualOperator_: Tests whether a value is greater than or equal to another value. Returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the expression is greater than or equal to the value on the right-hand side of the expression.
dropletBlock_ifBlock_description: Executes a block of statements if the specified condition is true
dropletBlock_ifElseBlock_description: Executes a block of statements if the specified condition is true; otherwise, the block of statements in the else clause are executed
dropletBlock_inequalityOperator_descript: Tests whether two values are not equal. Returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the expression does not equal the value on the right-hand side of the expression
dropletBlock_lessThanOperator_descriptio: Tests whether a value is less than another value. Returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the expression is strictly less than the value on the right-hand side of the expression
dropletBlock_lessThanOrEqualOperator_des: Tests whether a value is less than or equal to another value. Returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the expression is less than or equal to the value on the right-hand side of the expression.
dropletBlock_mathAbs_description: Takes the absolute value of x
dropletBlock_mathMax_description: Takes the maximum value among one or more values n1, n2, ..., nX
dropletBlock_mathMax_param0_description: One or more numbers to compare.
dropletBlock_mathMin_description: Takes the minimum value among one or more values n1, n2, ..., nX
dropletBlock_mathMin_param0_description: One or more numbers to compare.
dropletBlock_mathPow_description: Takes x to the power of y
dropletBlock_mathRandom_description: Returns a random number ranging from 0 (inclusive) up to but not including 1 (exclusive)
dropletBlock_mathRound_description: Rounds a number to the nearest integer
dropletBlock_mathSqrt_description: Returns the square root of x
dropletBlock_moduloOperator_description: Returns the remainder of a division problem
dropletBlock_notOperator_description: Returns false if the expression can be converted to true; otherwise, returns true
dropletBlock_orOperator_description: Returns true when either expression is true and false otherwise
dropletBlock_playSound_description: Plays the MP3 sound file from the specified URL.
dropletBlock_playSound_param0_descriptio: The URL to a sound file. Can be a project asset name or external URL.
dropletBlock_playSound_param1_descriptio: If true, loop the sound until asked to stop.
dropletBlock_playSpeech_description: Plays the specified text as speech with a voice in the specified gender. Powered by Microsoft Azure AI.
dropletBlock_randomNumber_description: Returns a random number in the closed range from min to max.
dropletBlock_return_description: Return a value from a function
dropletBlock_stopSound_description: Stops playing the sound file from the specified URL, or all sounds if no URL is given.
dropletBlock_stopSound_param0_descriptio: The URL to a sound file. Can be an project asset name or external URL.
dropletBlock_whileBlock_description: Creates a loop consisting of a conditional expression and a block of statements executed for each iteration of the loop. The loop continues to execute as long as the condition evaluates to true

eligibilityExplanation: In order to be eligible to receive a code for a subsidized Circuit Playground kit, you must meet the following requirements:
eligibilityReqPD: You attended a 5-day summer workshop for CS Discoveries in 2019 or are participating in the 2019-20 Facilitator Development Program as a new CS Discoveries facilitator.
eligibilityReqStudentCount: Ten students in one of your sections have completed the first three units of CS Discoveries.
eligibilityReqStudentCountFail: Sorry, it doesn't look like you have enough students in your sections that have made progress in Units 2 and 3. Please check back here once your students have finished the first semester of CS Discoveries. If you are using a different account to track the progress of students or if you think there has been an error in detecting how much progress your students have made in Units 2 and 3, please contact us at teacher@code.org.
eligibilityReqYear: You plan to teach Unit 6 by the end of the 2020-21 school year.
eligibilityReqYearConfirmInstructions: Please confirm that you will be teaching Unit 6 of CS Discoveries with your students and when you will be teaching it:
eligibilityReqYearFail: The subsidy for classroom kits of the Adafruit Circuit Playground is available thanks to the generosity of Code.org's donors such as Microsoft, Facebook, Infosys Foundation, Omidyar Network, and Google. Additionally, Adafruit and DHL are helping to lower the cost of these kits directly. Our intention is that these subsidized kits are going to teachers who are teaching all units of CS Discoveries to their students (whether over 1 or 2 years), as we want to lower the barrier to teaching a hardware-based unit.
eligibilitySchoolUnknown: Because your school isn't listed, we were not able to look up the data on what percent of your students are eligible for free/reduced-price lunches.
eligibilityYearDecline: Unfortunately, we can only offer codes for subsidized kits for teachers who know they will be teaching Unit 6 of CS Discoveries by the '20-'21 school year. For any questions or concerns, please contact us at teacher@code.org.
eligibilityYearNo: No, I am not planning on teaching Unit 6 of CS Discoveries.
eligibilityYearYesFall2020: Yes, I plan on teaching it during fall 2020.
eligibilityYearYesSpring2020: Yes, I plan on teaching it during spring 2020.
eligibilityYearYesSpring2021: Yes, I plan on teaching it during spring 2021.
emailAddressPolicy: Code.org will not store student email addresses in a retrievable format, for privacy reasons.

emptySectionDescription: You haven't added students to this class section yet. Add some students to start tracking their progress.
emptySurveyOverviewTable:
Because this survey is anonymous, we can only show aggregated results once at least 5 students have submitted their survey and answered the first question of the survey. 

If you have given this survey to your class and are still not seeing responses here, please give the survey to your class again and encourage your students to answer the first question of the survey before they submit the survey. [Learn more about surveys and assessments.](https://support.code.org/hc/articles/115001331951-Using-lock-settings-for-assessments-and-surveys)
emptyTextResponsesTable: Most of our classes are designed to work for younger ages and do not require students to type text responses to questions, so you will not see any text responses here. explainCourseAssignmentsLearnMore: Learn what happens when you assign a course.
explainLessonExtras: When Lesson Extras is on, students will end each lesson with some bonus challenges and creative projects rather than being automatically advanced to the next lesson. This feature gives students the opportunity to expand their knowledge and further practice, without getting ahead of their classmates.
explainLessonExtrasToolsTip: When Lesson Extras is on, students will end each lesson with some bonus challenges and creative projects rather than being automatically advanced to the next lesson. This feature gives students the opportunity to expand their knowledge and further practice, without getting ahead of their classmates.  Not available in all courses and units.
explainPairProgramming: When pair programming is turned on, students can choose to work with a classmate at the same computer. Turn this setting on if you want students to be able to work together while sharing progress.
explainRestrictedSectionEmail: If set to ‘yes,’ students will not be able to join this section using the section code. You can still add students to the section manually by moving or copying them from another section.
explainRestrictedSectionEmailToolTip: If set to ‘yes,’ students will not be able to join this section using the section code. You can still add students to the section manually by moving or copying them from another section.

explainTtsAutoplay: For Chrome, Internet Explorer, and Edge browsers only: When this setting is on, level instructions will be automatically read aloud to students using text-to-speech each time they open a level. This makes it easier for students who are not yet fluent readers to complete lessons.
explainTtsAutoplayToolTip: For Chrome, Internet Explorer, and Edge browsers only: When this setting is on, level instructions will be automatically read aloud to students using text-to-speech each time they open a level. This makes it easier for students who are not yet fluent readers to complete lessons. Not available in all courses.
expressCourseDescription: Learn computer science at your own pace! Learn to create computer programs, develop problem-solving skills, and work through fun challenges! Make games and creative projects to share with friends, family, and teachers.

loginCardForPrint1: 1.) Go to [{directLink}]({directLink}) or to [{joinLink}]({joinLink}) and type in your 6-letter section code: **{sectionCode}**
loginExportInstructions: **Teaching remotely?** Download a CSV of student login information so you can do a mail merge or easily copy and paste each student's username and password into emails.
loginInfoLtiSetupBody:
To get a class set up with {providerName}, please do the following:
1. Ensure your class is set up the way you want it to be in {providerName} (e.g. the students are rostered in the sections you desire).
1. Click the "Sync students & sections" button above to copy {providerName} students & sections into Code.org.

You're finished! If you ever need to add or remove sections & students later, do that in {providerName} first, then re-sync your classroom again with the "Sync students & sections" button above.
loginInfoLtiUpdateBody:
In order to update your sections, please do the following:
1. Ensure your class is set up the way you want it to be in {providerName}
1. Click "Launch Code.org" or
Click "Sync sections & students" from the Manage Students tab
loginInfoResetSecretPicDesc: You can reset the picture password for any of your students by going to the [Manage Students]({url}) tab for the section, clicking the "Show picture" button under the " Picture password" column, and clicking the "Reset" button.
loginInfoResetSecretWordDesc: You can reset the secret words for any of your students by going to the [Manage Students]({url}) tab for the section, clicking the "Show words" button under the "Secret words" column, and clicking the "Reset" button.
loginInfoWordPicMoreBelow: Students can find all of this information, including their secret {wordOrPicture}, in the login cards below.
loginInfo_joinBody: If a student has not yet joined your section, please ask them to perform the following steps. Note that they only need to do this once. By joining your section, students will be able see the course assigned to them and you will be able to track the progress of the work they complete while they are signed in.
loginInfo_joinStep1: Create a Code.org account if they haven’t already done so. They can do this at {url}. Note that they can either sign up with an email address and password, or sign up through Google, Facebook, or Microsoft by clicking on one of these buttons:
loginInfo_joinStep1Buttons: Screenshot of three buttons, reading 'Continue with Google', 'Continue with Facebook', and 'Continue with Microsoft'
loginInfo_joinStep2: Sign in to their Code.org account.
loginInfo_joinStep4: Once they press the "Go" button, they should be added to your section.
loginInfo_noStudents: *It looks like you don't have any students in this section! Add some students in the [Manage Students]({url}) tab for this section.*
loginInfo_oauthSectionCodes: {provider} sections do not have 6-digit section codes, so your student will not need to use a section code to login.
loginInfo_resetPasswordBody: If your student created a Code.org account using their email address and password (rather than signing in through Google, Facebook, Microsoft, or Clever), you can reset their password by going to the [Manage Students]({url}) tab of your section and clicking the "Reset password" button in the "Password" column.
loginInfo_signinSteps: Your students can sign in to their Code.org accounts by following these steps:
loginInfo_signingInClever: Your students should sign in to their Code.org accounts by going to their Clever dashboard and clicking the Code.org logo.
loginInfo_signingInDescription: Your students can sign in to their Code.org accounts by going to https://code.org and clicking the "Sign in" button in the top right corner.
loginInfo_signingInGoogle: From there, they should choose the "Continue with Google" option:

missionStatement: **Code.org®** is a nonprofit dedicated to expanding access to computer science in schools and increasing participation by women and underrepresented minorities. Our vision is that every student in every school has the opportunity to learn computer science, just like biology, chemistry or algebra. Code.org provides the leading curriculum for K-12 computer science in the largest school districts in the United States and Code.org also organizes the annual Hour of Code campaign which has engaged 15% of all students in the world. Code.org is supported by generous donors including Amazon, Facebook, Google, the Infosys Foundation, Microsoft, and many more.

parentLetterIntro: In my class, {studentName} is learning computer science on [Code.org]({homeLink}), a fun, creative platform for learning computer science and basic coding to create interactive animations, games, or apps. Your interest in what your child is learning is critical, and Code.org makes it easy to stay involved.
parentLetterLoginType: Our class uses **{loginTypeName}** to sign in. To have your student sign in to Code.org at home, do the following:
parentLetterPicturePassword: Click on their picture password and then click 'Sign in'
parentLetterPicturePasswordImg: Picture password image for your student.
parentLetterSecretWords: Type in their secret words {secretWords} and then click 'Sign in'
parentLetterSectionSignIn: Go to [{sectionLink}]({sectionLink}) and click on their name
parentLetterSignInEmail: Have them enter their email and password and then click 'Sign In'
parentLetterStep1: Step 1 - Encourage your child, show interest in computer science
parentLetterStep1Details: One of the best ways is to ask your child to explain what they’re learning and show you a project they are proud of, [see details]({engagementLink}). Or watch one of these [videos]({videosLink}) together.
parentLetterStep2: Step 2 - Get your child set up to use Code.org at home
parentLetterStep2Details: At the top of their homepage, {studentName} can continue the course they are doing with their classroom at school. They can also create their own [games or artwork in the Project Gallery]({projectsLink}) or check out [code.org/athome]({atHomeLink}) for ideas for things to work on at home.
parentLetterStep2Details_LMS: If this is {studentName}'s first time signing-in from {loginTypeName}, they will have the option to create a new Code.org account, or link to their existing Code.org account.
parentLetterStep3: Step 3 - Connect your email to your student's account
parentLetterStep3Details: Keep up to date with what your student is working on and receive updates from Code.org. Have your child sign in to Code.org and then enter your email in Account Settings or [click here]({accountEditLink}).
parentLetterStudentPrivacyDetails: Code.org assigns utmost importance to student safety and security. As a not-for-profit organization, they are transparent about the limited data they collect and how they use it.  They do not sell data or exploit it for financial gain. They do not sell ads. Code.org has signed the [Student Privacy Pledge]({pledgeLink}) and their privacy practices are highly rated by [Common Sense Media]({commonSenseLink}). You can find further details by viewing Code.org's [Privacy Policy]({privacyPolicyLink}).
parentLetterWhyDetails: [Six different studies show]({researchLink}): children who study computer science perform better in other subjects, excel at problem solving, and are 17% more likely to attend college. Computer science teaches students critical thinking, problem solving, and digital citizenship, and benefits all students, no matter what opportunities they pursue in the future. And learning to make interactive animations, code-art, games, and apps on Code.org encourages creativity and makes learning fun.

projectSharingDialogHeader: Control sharing for App Lab / Game Lab / Web Lab projects
projectSharingDialogInstructions:
App Lab, Game Lab and Web Lab are programming environments that allow students to personalize and customize their creations through writing free-form text, uploading images and sounds, etc. By default, students under the age of 13 are not able to share their projects with others, but students aged 13 and over are.

 If you want to be able to manage exactly which students can and can not share these project types, you can show the project sharing column by clicking the button below.

rubricTourConfidenceText: The confidence rating gives you an idea of how often your AI Teaching Assistant agreed with other teachers when scoring this learning goal. Just like humans, your AI Teaching Assistant isn't perfect.

rubricTourUnderstandingText: Your AI Teaching Assistant analyzes students’ code for each learning goal, then suggests one or two rubric scores. It will suggest one score for learning goals where it has trained extensively and two scores where more training data is needed. The final score is always up to you. In each case, your AI Teaching Assistant will provide evidence for its suggestion.

setUpClassCleverIntro: To get your class set up with Clever, do the following:
setUpClassEmail1: 1. Have your students [create Code.org accounts]({createAccountLink}) with their own email addresses. Note: The creation by students under 13 of personal logins requires a separate parental consent step (i.e., an email to parent/guardian and an affirmative response) that may delay or prevent account creation and interfere with classroom participation. We therefore strongly recommend the use of picture password or secret word accounts for classes with students under 13. If they already have a Code.org account associated with their email address, they can skip this step.

shareSettingDisableButtonDescription: If you need to block your students from sharing projects created through Code.org's advanced tools (App Lab, Game Lab, and Web Lab) that allow students to write free-form text, upload their own images and sounds, etc., you can do so by clicking on the 'Disable sharing advanced projects for all students' button below.
shareSettingDisableDialog: An important part of the student experience of using Code.org is the ability to share their projects and creations with others. With sharing disabled, students will not be able to share their creations created with our advanced programming tools (App Lab, Game Lab, and Web Lab) with anyone else besides their Code.org teachers. These advanced tools are designed for students that are over 13 or being used under a teacher or parent’s guidance.
shareSettingDisableDialogNote: Note that students will still be able to share projects created using the programming tools designed for younger students like Play Lab and Artist. These tools limit what students can create and do not allow for uploading any of their own assets. To protect students’ privacy, shared creations in the project gallery are labeled only with the first letter of a student’s name and an age range.

standardsGetInvolvedDetails: Learn how to get your [administrators]({adminLink}), [parents]({parentLink}), and [fellow teachers]({teacherLink}) involved in CS education.
standardsGetInvolvedDetailsForPrint: Learn more about how you can support computer science education as an [administrator]({adminLink}), [parent]({parentLink}), or [teacher]({teacherLink}).
standardsHowToDetails: This report shows how Code.org's [{courseName}]({courseLink}) maps to [CSTA Standards]({cstaLink}) and how many lessons in {courseName} this class has completed. Completing all lessons for a standards does not automatically indicate mastery of that standard - please use your best judgement to determine how well the class or individual students have learned the course material. For reference, a Code.org lesson is approximately 45 - 65 minutes of instructional time. A "plugged" online lesson is considered "in progress" when at least 20% of the enrolled students have completed 20% of the lesson.  A "plugged" online lesson is considered "complete" when 80% of the enrolled students have finished 60% of the lesson. Unplugged lessons can be marked "complete" or "incomplete" by the teacher.
standardsHowToDetailsForPrint: This report shows how Code.org's [{courseName}]({courseLink}) maps to [CSTA Standards]({cstaLink}) and how many lessons in {courseName} this class has completed. Completing all lessons for a standard does not automatically indicate mastery of that standard - please check with your teacher to get specific information about how well the class or individual students have learned the course material. For reference, a Code.org lesson is approximately 45 - 65 minutes of instructional time. A "plugged" online lesson is considered "in progress" when at least 20% of the enrolled students have completed 20% of the lesson.  A "plugged" online lesson is considered "complete" when 80% of the enrolled students have finished 60% of the lesson. Unplugged lessons can be marked "complete" or "incomplete" by the teacher.
standardsReminder: **Remember:** Completing all lessons for a standard **does not automatically indicate mastery** of that standard - please use your best judgement to determine how well your students have learned course material.
